== Who I Am ==

My name is Benjamin Wheeler, and I have been a member of the Ubuntu Kernel Team
since September 2024.

I received a Master's Degree in Electrical and Computer Engineering from the University of Florida in 2021.
I have used Linux in academic, professional, and personal contexts for approximately the last 5 years.
I received my kernel team commit rights in February 2025.

== My Ubuntu Story ==

I first reached for Ubuntu in my college years (around 2019) when I discovered its benefits for software development. 
After liking WSL but wanting more, I began daily-driving Ubuntu (and other various Linux distributions) on all my machines.
I've been daily-driving Linux for at least the past 5 years on my personal machines, and used other distributions (typically RHEL)
in professional contexts prior to working at Canonical.

=== My Involvement ===

Since joining Canonical, I've been working on real-time Linux kernel releases. I have recently begun work on improving testing
and performance benchmarking of these kernels as well.

Other kernels I have prepared:

* focal:linux-oracle (reviewed by Philip Cox) for the s2025.03.17 and 2025.04.14 cycles.

* bionic:linux-raspi-5.4 (reviewed by Philip Cox) for the 2025.01.13 cycle.

* focal:linux-denver (reviewed by Mehmet Basaran) for the 2025.02.10 and s2025.02.10 cycles.

* xenial:linux-azure (reviewed by Bethany Jamison) for the s2024.12.02 cycle.

== Plans for the Future ==

I plan to deepen my understanding of our real-time and performance testing processes, as well as our SRU kernel workflows.

=== Philip Cox ===
==== General feedback ====
==== Specific Experiences of working together ====
''I have been reviewing Benjamin's kernel cranks regularly since he has been cranking kernels for the kernel team.  In the early kernels, there may have been small corrections required occasionally, but after issues were pointed out, he did not repeat the errors.  His recent kernel cranks are of a very high quality, and he has shown  to have a good sense of when to reach out for help.  In a recent kernel crank, there was a merge conflict with a upstream patch and a SAUCE patch.  He understood the implications, and reached out to me to discuss the best options.  

I trust him to make solid choices, and think he should be granted kernel upload rights.  He produces high quality kernels, and has shown sound judgement when a difficult decision was required.  ''
